citation.article-title: Rhodococcus sputi sp. nov., nom. rev,. and Rhodococcus aurantiacus sp.nov., nom. rev.

p.s: Description of Rhodococcus aurantiacus (ex Tsukamura and Mizuno 1971; Tsukamura 1974) sp. nov., nom. rev.
Rhodococcus aurantiacus (au. ran. ti'a. cus. L. adj. aurantiacus orange colored)
Synonym, Gordona auruntiaca Tsukamura and Mizuno 1971.
The following description of Rhodococcus aurantiacus is based on 11 strains.
Gram-positive, weakly acid-fast rods (2 to 5 by 0.5 μm).
Some strains are strongly acid fast.
Mycelium is not formed.
Nonsporeforming.
Rough, dry, brownish, scotochromogenic colonies are formed on egg media and on Sauton agar when glutamate is substituted for asparagine.
Abundant growth occurs after 3 days.
Growth occurs at 28 and 37°C but not at 42°C.
Resistant to 20 μg of 5-fluorouracil per ml and to 5 μg of mitomycin C per ml in Ogawa egg medium.
Susceptible to 5 pg of bleomycin per ml in Sauton agar.

Resistant to sodium para-aminosalicylate (2 mg/ml), sodium salicylate (0.5 mg/ml), para-nitrobenzoic acid (0.5 mg/ml), hydroxylamine hydrochloride (0.5 mg/ml), ethambutol (5 μg/ml), rifampin (25 μg/ml), isoniazid (10 μg/ml), and 5% sodium chloride in Ogawa egg medium and in Lowenstein-Jensen medium.
Resistant to 0.2% picric acid, 0.1% sodium salicylate, and 0.2% sodium nitrite in Sauton agar.
Niacin is not produced.
para-Aminosalicylate and salicylate are not degraded to catechol.
Arylsulfatase negative (14 days).
Catalase is produced.
Tween 80 is usually hydrolyzed after 14 days.
β-Galactosidase is produced.
Acid phosphatase is not produced.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite after 24 h.
Acetamidase, urease, nicotinamidase, pyrazinamidase, and allantoinase are produced, but benzamidase, isonicotinamidase, salicylamidase, and succinamidase are not.
Glutamate, serine, D-glucosamine hydrochloride, acetamide, and monoethanolamine are utilized as simultaneous nitrogen and carbon sources, but benzamide and trimethylenediamine are not.
Acetate, citrate, succinate, L-malate, pyruvate, and fumarate are utilized as sole carbon sources in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen, but benzoate and malonate are not.

Glucose, fructose, sucrose, mannose, galactose, trehalose, inositol, mannitol, and sorbitol are utilized as sole carbon sources in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen, but L-arabinose, D-xylose, and L-rhamnose are not.
Acid is formed from glucose, D-mannose, D-galactose, trehalose, inositol, mannitol, and sorbitol.
Acid is not formed from L-arabinose, D-xylose, and L-rhamnose.

Ethanol, n-propanol, propylene glycol, n-butanol, isobutanol, and 2,3-butylene glycol are utilized as sole carbon sources in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen, but 1,3-butylene glycol and 1,4-butylene glycol are not.
Serine, acetamide, urea, pyrazinamide, nicotinamide, and nitrate are utilized as sole nitrogen sources in the presence of glycerol as a carbon source.
Nitrite is utilized by some strains.
On silica gel thin-layer chromatography plates, two adjacent spots, corresponding to mycolic acids possessing different straight-chain and alpha-alkyl branch structures, are detected.
The lower spot contains monoenoic, dienoic, trienoic, and tetraenoic mycolic acids having 62 to 74 carbon atoms.
The upper spot contains dienoic to hexanoic (heptanoic) mycolic acids having 64 to 78 carbon atoms.

Based on the numbers of carbon atoms in the mycolic acids, R. aurantiacus appears to be closely related to mycobacteria, and based on the number of double bonds, it appears to be closely related to nocardiae and rhodococci.
The details have been described by Tomiyasu and Yano (14).
The mycolic acids of this organism have also been studied by Goodfellow et al. (5).
Characteristics which differentiate this species from other species of the genus Rhodococcus are shown in Table 1.
Occurs in the sputum of human patients with lung disease.
This species may be a lung pathogen.
The type strain is strain ATCC 25938.
Description of the type strain.
Strain ATCC 25938T has all of the properties given above for the species except the following.
This strain is almost strongly acid fast.
It grows at 42°C but not at 45°C.
It is susceptible to 0.5 mg of hydroxylamine per ml and resistant to 0.25 mg of hydroxylamine per ml in Ogawa egg medium and Lowenstein-Jensen medium.
Tween 80 is not hydrolyzed after 14 days.
Nitrite is utilized as a sole nitrogen source.
Strain ATCC 25938T was isolated from the sputum of a patient suffering from lung disease.
